Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 767, 560]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 757, 600]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 655, 905, 848]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate how the resistance of a filament lamp changes as the potential difference (p.d.) across it changes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 411, 136]]<|/det|> The circuit has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 576, 152]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 161, 819, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 414, 532, 433]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 447, 144, 465]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 336, 479]]<|/det|> Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 170, 510]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 492, 920, 526]]<|/det|> Adjust the position of the crocodile clip, so that the length \(l\) of the slide wire connected is \(20.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 540, 191, 557]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 539, 794, 558]]<|/det|> Record in Table 1.1 the value of the p.d. \(V\) and the current \(I\) for the lamp. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 571, 170, 588]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 570, 920, 603]]<|/det|> Move the crocodile clip and record values of \(V\) and \(I\) for \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}, 60.0 \text{cm}, 80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(100.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 617, 171, 635]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 617, 336, 635]]<|/det|> Open the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 650]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 663, 541, 681]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 694, 692, 848]]<|/det|>
l/cmV/VI/AR/Ω
20.0
40.0
60.0
80.0
100.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 861, 146, 878]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 860, 828, 878]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the resistance \(R\) of the lamp at each value of \(l\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 880, 358, 907]]<|/det|> Use the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 883, 920, 902]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 123]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 363, 811, 382]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 394, 453, 413]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 425, 799, 444]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 615, 89]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 98, 616, 317]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 337, 534, 355]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 368, 190, 387]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 368, 663, 387]]<|/det|> Hang a load \(L = 1.0 \text{N}\) on the spring as shown in Fig. 3.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 175, 418]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 399, 764, 418]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 431, 175, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 431, 615, 448]]<|/det|> Repeat the process for \(L\) values of 2.0 N and 3.0 N. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 462, 539, 479]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 494, 645, 604]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 843, 89]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating ways of slowing the rate of cooling of hot liquids in a container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The student knows that a lid will reduce the rate of cooling. He wants to find out if the thickness of the lid makes any difference to the rate of cooling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 902, 166]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effects of lids of different thicknesses. You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 324, 198]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 211, 405, 229]]<|/det|>
• list the apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 243, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 289, 690, 307]]<|/det|>
• state any key variables that would need to be kept the same

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 920, 353]]<|/det|>
• draw a suitable table or tables, with column headings, to show how the readings would be displayed (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 367, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
• explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 576, 415]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE
